Thomas L. Friedman (column, Aug. 4) suggests that most Americans care less about foreign affairs than about the economy. The electorate is fickle. Even a 90 percent approval rating of President Bush's handling of the Persian Gulf war wasn't enough to get him re-elected.

Gov. George W. Bush's campaign team understands this voter mentality. The failed Middle East peace talks, coupled with leadership changes in Syria and Jordan, demand that the next administration have a foreign policy ''A-team.''

To argue that Governor Bush ''has no reassuring economic wise men'' is off the mark. One of Mr. Bush's top advisers is George P. Shultz, who has a Ph.D. in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and has held four cabinet positions. The Republicans are covering all of the bases.
JAMES A. PALADINO Tampa, Fla., Aug. 4, 2000
